title.native: 超訳百人一首 うた恋い。

description: Uta Koi tells the "super-liberal interpretation" of the Hyakuninisshu anthology compiled during Japan's Heian period of 100 romantic poems from 100 different poets such as The Tale of Genji's Murasaki Shikibu.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Classic Literature
tags.description: Discusses or adapts a work of classic world literature.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Marriage
tags.description: Centers around marriage between two or more characters.

tags.name: Unrequited Love
tags.description: One or more characters are experiencing an unrequited love that may or may not be reciprocated.

title.native: 超訳百人一首　うた恋い。
超訳百人一首 うた恋い。酒と貴公子～藤式部と公任

node.description: Bro.Hi, short for "Brother High," is the alias of a former member of the Japanese hip-hop band SOUL'd OUT. He worked as the band's MC along with Diggy-MO' and Shinnosuke from 1999 to 2014, when the group ended its activities. Nowadays, he works as one of the lead singers of the band E.P.O. He is also known by the nicknames "Human Beat Box" and "Japonegro."

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/YasunoriMitsuda) | [Profile](https://www.procyon-studio.co.jp/staff/mitsuda/) | [Blog](https://www.procyon-studio.com/blog/)

Yasunori Mitsuda is a Japanese composer and musician. He is best known for his work in video games, primarily for the Chrono, Shadow Hearts, and Inazuma Eleven franchises, among various others. Mitsuda began composing music for his own games in high school, later attending the Junior College of Music in Tokyo. While still a student, he was granted an intern position at the game development studio Wolf Team.

Mitsuda later joined Square Co., Ltd.(now Square Enix) upon graduation in 1992 after seeing a magazine advertisement in an office he was visiting with his professor. He worked there as a sound effects designer for two years before telling Square's vice president [Hironobu Sakaguchi](https://anilist.co/staff/101047/Hironobu-Sakaguchi) he would quit unless he could write music for their games. Shortly after, Sakaguchi assigned him to work on the soundtrack for Chrono Trigger, whose music has since been cited as among the best in video games.

After Chrono Trigger's success and the music's acclaim. Mitsuda went on to compose for several other games at Square, including Xenogears (1998) and Chrono Cross (1999). He left the company and became independent in 1998.

In 2001, he respectively founded his own music production studio and record company, Procyon Studio and Sleigh Bells. Mitsuda has also contributed music for anime series, films, and television programs, as well as producing albums.

Best known as the creator of [Project A-Ko](https://anilist.co/anime/212/). He is particularly noted for his work during the ‘80s, going all out in [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/) and many OVAs and films such as [Outlanders](https://anilist.co/anime/1940/) and [Dirty Pair](https://anilist.co/anime/1796/). He is among the many [Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)-influenced animators of the ‘80s, and his work is recognizable from its wide-eyed characters, attention to anatomical detail, and characterful impact frames.

Initially he wanted to be a mangaka, but enrolled in university instead after not being sure if he could make a living - though, he did drop out after a year. During his short lived time there, he was watching [Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) and had sent a letter to [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/) with the hopes of joining [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/). They weren’t accepting in-betweeners at this time, so a producer of theirs referred him to [Studio Live](https://anilist.co/studio/6460/), which he then joined after passing an entrance test in 1979. There he studied under the studio’s founder, [Toyoo Ashida](https://anilist.co/staff/110953/), and started gaining attention for his work on Urusei Yatsura.

After working at [Studio Deen](https://anilist.co/studio/37/) for a while, he took part in the establishment of Studio Graviton alongside [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/), [Shouichi Masuo](https://anilist.co/staff/133909/) and [Kouji Itou](https://anilist.co/staff/101166/). He then went freelance and worked regularly for [Studio Fantasia](https://anilist.co/studio/24/).

Lately he has shifted more and more towards directing and storyboarding rather than animating himself, often collaborating with his long-time friends [Yuuji Moriyama](https://anilist.co/staff/100658/) and [Noriyasu Yamauchi](https://anilist.co/staff/112903/).

ecosystem is a Japanese band formed in Osaka. Their alternative and progressive rock swallowed all genres sound with real lyrics, everyday cut and fit the melody mixed with a unique blend. They were an indie band, releasing Jean mini album in 2010, until went major with the single Dilemma in November 2011 that was also the opening theme for the anime Gintama.

SOUL'd OUT was a Japanese hip-hop trio consisting of [Diggy-MO'](https://anilist.co/staff/101708) (MC), [Bro.Hi](https://anilist.co/staff/101709/BroHi) (MC/Human Beat Box), and Shinnosuke (DJ).

On January 30, 2014, they announced on Facebook that they would disband after their final album, To From, which was released on April 9, 2014.
